prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of [CI](1-0) using our dust masses (see science case) as an indicator of the H2 mass such that M_H2~150 M_d (where 150 is the Milky Way gas-to-dust ratio that holds for nearby galaxies). [CI](1-0) line intensities are then estimated using Equ. 12 in Papadopoulos et al. (2004), which converts MH2 to [CI] line flux in Jy kms/s. We used the following values for parameters, as in the ALMA predictions by Papadopoulos \& Geach (2012): Q_{10} = 0.35, X_{CI} = 3e5, A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1. 12CO(1-0) line intensities are estimated from the relation MH2-1.1x10^{4} D_{L}^{2} (1+z)^{-1} S_{CO}(1-0), which assumes a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 2.0x10^{20} H_{2} cm^{-2} / [K kms/s] which is appropriate for quiescent star forming galaxies. This gives [CI] integrated intensities of 10-150 Jy km/s, which were translated into rms sensitivities assuming a line width of 300 km/s and S/N of >2 for [CI] per 50 km/s velocity channel. In addition, we took into account that the CI emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (1'' corresponds to ~1.5 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half. The optical (SDSS) angular size of the sources is typically ~7-8''. We assume that the CO/CI emitting region is about 1/3-half the size of the optical diameter for each velocity bin (e.g. Gao, 1996; Young et al. 1985). Thus we estimate the molecular gas emission to lie within a region typically of ~3-4'' diameter. We then grouped sources into as few Science Goals as possible in order to minimize overheads and total observing time, so in some cases it was more efficient to observe a target to a better sensitivity if it meant sharing calibrators in a Science Goal. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N.
For [CI](1-0) we request a sensitivity of 4 mJy rms for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of 0.4 mJy/beam.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 2.44 minutes per target or a total of 1.33h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.
Imaging ========
We wish to image the targets in the [CI](1-0) transition using the C34-1 configuration, providing an angular resolution of 0.8''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron), and while we expect them to be resolved with ALMA in Band 8 (since the beam will be ~0.8'') we do not expect the sources to be more extended than 5-6'' (~3'' radius) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13'' primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5-6'' (~1.2 kpc). Thus, use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 2 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a uv-taper.
Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the [CI](1-0) line, in Band 8, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be $\sim$300 km/s, and to optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s (justified given the assumed line width). In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CO line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.

Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of [CI](1-0) using our dust masses (see science case) as an indicator of the H2 mass such that M_H2~150 M_d (where 150 is the Milky Way gas-to-dust ratio that holds for nearby galaxies). [CI](1-0) line intensities are then estimated using Equ. 12 in Papadopoulos et al. (2004), which converts MH2 to [CI] line flux in Jy kms/s. We used the following values for parameters, as in the ALMA predictions by Papadopoulos \& Geach (2012): Q_{10} = 0.35, X_{CI} = 3e5, A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1. 12CO(1-0) line intensities are estimated from the relation MH2-1.1x10^{4} D_{L}^{2} (1+z)^{-1} S_{CO}(1-0), which assumes a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 2.0x10^{20} H_{2} cm^{-2} / [K kms/s] which is appropriate for quiescent star forming galaxies. This gives [CI] integrated intensities of 10-150 Jy km/s, which were translated into rms sensitivities assuming a line width of 300 km/s and S/N of >2 for [CI] per 50 km/s velocity channel. In addition, we took into account that the CI emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (1'' corresponds to ~1.5 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half. The optical (SDSS) angular size of the sources is typically ~7-8''. We assume that the CO/CI emitting region is about 1/3-half the size of the optical diameter for each velocity bin (e.g. Gao, 1996; Young et al. 1985). Thus we estimate the molecular gas emission to lie within a region typically of ~3-4'' diameter. We then grouped sources into as few Science Goals as possible in order to minimize overheads and total observing time, so in some cases it was more efficient to observe a target to a better sensitivity if it meant sharing calibrators in a Science Goal. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N.
For [CI](1-0) we request a sensitivity of 1.3 mJy rms for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of 0.13 mJy/beam.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 22 minutes per target or a total of 2.5h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.
Imaging ========
We wish to image the targets in the [CI](1-0) transition using the C34-1 configuration, providing an angular resolution of 0.8''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron), and while we expect them to be resolved with ALMA in Band 8 (since the beam will be ~0.8'') we do not expect the sources to be more extended than 5-6'' (~3'' radius) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13'' primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5-6'' (~1.2 kpc). Thus, use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 2 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a uv-taper.
Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the [CI](1-0) line, in Band 8, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be $\sim$300 km/s, and to optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s (justified given the assumed line width). In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CO line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.

Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of 12CO(1-0) by using our dust masses (see science case) an indicator of the H2 mass such that M_H2~150 M_d (where 150 is the Milky Way gas-to-dust ratio that holds for nearby galaxies). 12CO(1-0) line intensities are estimated from the relation MH2-1.1x10^{4} D_{L}^{2} (1+z)^{-1} S_{CO}(1-0), which assumes a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 2.0x10^{20} H_{2} cm^{-2} / [K kms/s] which is appropriate for quiescent star forming galaxies (Bolato et al. 2013). This gives CO line intensities of 3-30 Jy km/s, which were translated into rms sensitivities assuming a line width of 300 km/s and S/N of >3 for CO per 50 km/s velocity channel. In addition, we took into account that the CO emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (corresponding to about 1 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half. The optical (SDSS) angular size of the sources is typically ~7-8''. We assume that the CO/CI emitting region is about 1/3-half the size of the optical diameter for each velocity bin (e.g. Gao, 1996; Young et al. 1985). Thus we estimate the molecular gas emission to lie within a region typically of ~3-4'' diameter. We then grouped sources into as few Science Goals as possible in order to minimize overheads and total observing time, so in some cases it was more efficient to observe a target to a better sensitivity if it meant sharing calibrators in a Science Goal. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of up to 0.07 mJy/beam in Band 3.
For CO(1-0) we request a sensitivity of 1.4 mJy/b for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 2.15 minutes per target or a total of 45 minutes to complete this SG.
Imaging ========
We wish to image CO(1-0) at an angular resolution of 2''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron), and while we expect them to be resolved with the ALMA beam. We do not expect the sources to be more extended than 5-6'' (~3'' radius) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13 arcsecond primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5-6'' (XX parsec at the average distance of these sources). Thus, use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 2 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result for these snapshots by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a uv-taper.
Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the CO(1-0) line, in Band 3, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be $\sim$300 km/s, and to optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s. In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CO line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.
Smoothing spectrally to 50 km/s is justified since we estimate line widths of ~300 km/s.
Calibration ========
We require standard observatory-defined calibration.
Bandpass accuracy ============
We do not require higher than standard bandpass accuracy to achieve our science goals.

Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of 12CO(1-0) by using our dust masses (see science case) an indicator of the H2 mass such that M_H2~150 M_d (where 150 is the Milky Way gas-to-dust ratio that holds for nearby galaxies). 12CO(1-0) line intensities are estimated from the relation MH2-1.1x10^{4} D_{L}^{2} (1+z)^{-1} S_{CO}(1-0), which assumes a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 2.0x10^{20} H_{2} cm^{-2} / [K kms/s] which is appropriate for quiescent star forming galaxies (Bolato et al. 2013). This gives CO line intensities of 3-30 Jy km/s, which were translated into rms sensitivities assuming a line width of 300 km/s and S/N of >3 for CO per 50 km/s velocity channel. In addition, we took into account that the CO emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (corresponding to about 1 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half. The optical (SDSS) angular size of the sources is typically ~7-8''. We assume that the CO/CI emitting region is about 1/3-half the size of the optical diameter for each velocity bin (e.g. Gao, 1996; Young et al. 1985). Thus we estimate the molecular gas emission to lie within a region typically of ~3-4'' diameter. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of up to 0.07 mJy/beam in Band 3.

According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 2.15 minutes per target or a total of 45 minutes to complete this SG.

We wish to image CO(1-0) at an angular resolution of 2''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron), and while we expect them to be resolved with the ALMA beam. We do not expect the sources to be more extended than 5-6'' (~3'' radius) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13 arcsecond primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5-6'' (XX parsec at the average distance of these sources). Thus, use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 2 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result for these snapshots by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a uv-taper.
Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the CO(1-0) line, in Band 3, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be $\sim$300 km/s, and to optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s. In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CO line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.
Smoothing spectrally to 50 km/s is justified since we estimate line widths of ~300 km/s.
Calibration ========
We require standard observatory-defined calibration.
Bandpass accuracy ============
We do not require higher than standard bandpass accuracy to achieve our science goals.

Sensitivity: ========
We estimate the line intensities of [CI](1-0) using our dust masses (see science case) as an indicator of the H2 mass such that M_H2~150 M_d (where 150 is the Milky Way gas-to-dust ratio that holds for nearby galaxies). [CI](1-0) line intensities are then estimated using Equ. 12 in Papadopoulos et al. (2004), which converts MH2 to [CI] line flux in Jy kms/s. We used the following values for parameters, as in the ALMA predictions by Papadopoulos \& Geach (2012): Q_{10} = 0.35, X_{CI} = 3e5, A_ul=7.93x10^-8 s^-1. 12CO(1-0) line intensities are estimated from the relation MH2-1.1x10^{4} D_{L}^{2} (1+z)^{-1} S_{CO}(1-0), which assumes a CO-to-H2 conversion factor of 2.0x10^{20} H_{2} cm^{-2} / [K kms/s] which is appropriate for quiescent star forming galaxies. This gives [CI] integrated intensities of 10-150 Jy km/s, which were translated into rms sensitivities assuming a line width of 300 km/s and S/N of >2 for [CI] per 50 km/s velocity channel. In addition, we took into account that the CI emission will be clumpy rather than smooth over the extent of the galaxy, and assume that each beam (1'' corresponds to ~1.5 kpc at the distance of z~0.07) has a filling factor of about a half. Thus we estimate the molecular gas emission to lie within a region typically of ~3-4'' diameter. We also assumed a minimum integration time on source of ~2 minutes to ensure good data quality and uv-coverage. Thus, in many cases for both lines we will detect the lines at higher S/N.
For [CI](1-0) we request a sensitivity of 2 mJy rms for a final spectral resolution of 50 km/s. In addition, we will get a continuum sensitivity of 0.2 mJy/beam.
According to the Sensitivity Calculator in the ALMA Observing Tool, we will need to integrate on-source for 9 minutes per target or a total of 1.6h (incl. overheads) to complete this SG.
Imaging ========
We wish to image the targets in the [CI](1-0) transition using the C34-1 configuration, providing an angular resolution of 0.8''. The galaxies are unresolved in the Herschel SPIRE bands, where the smallest beamsize is ~18'' (at 250 micron), and while we expect them to be resolved with ALMA in Band 8 (since the beam will be ~0.8'') we do not expect the sources to be more extended than 5-6'' (~3'' radius) and so will fit within the inner 1/3 of the 13'' primary beam/field of view. We therefore also do not expect emission on scales larger than ~5-6'' (~1.2 kpc). Thus, use of the ACA is not required. With the number of antennas available for Cycle 2 we will achieve a good uv-coverage for imaging in the requested time, even for these relative 'snapshots'. We will further achieve a good imaging result by carefully cleaning the data and if appropriate applying a uv-taper.
Correlator Setup ===========
We wish to observe the [CI](1-0) line, in Band 8, using a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz and 0.976 MHz channel spacing (including online Hanning smoothing). We have conservatively assumed line widths to be $\sim$300 km/s, and to optimize between sensitivity and spectral resolution, we will then smooth our data to a final velocity resolution of 50 km/s (justified given the assumed line width). In addition to the one spectral window which we will place on the CO line, we will use the remaining three spectral windows (2 GHz bandwidth TDM mode spectral windows, which have 31.25 MHz channel spacing) to obtain the continuum emission. The continuum will be obtained over a total of 7.5 GHz, omitting the spectral lines in the band.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We wish to use ALMA to obtain the first spatially resolved and sensitive imaging of the [CI](1-0) and 12CO(1-0) lines in a sample of nearby (z~0.07) Herschel Astrophysical TeraHertz Large Area Survey (H-ATLAS) galaxies detected by their dust content, in order to trace their molecular hydrogen content. A key problem in astronomy is how to reliably measure the amount of H2 in galaxies since a significant proportion may be missed when observed via the traditional tracer, the CO molecule. With the new ALMA Band 8 receivers we will be able to carry out the first observations of the[CI](1-0) fine structure line of atomic carbon in a sample of galaxies in the nearby (z~0.07) Universe and, together with the standard tracer CO(1-0), will be able to address: a) whether molecular gas in nearby galaxies is well-traced by CO or whether [CI] is a better tracer of the bulk of the H2, b) how the molecular gas mass and corresponding gas-to-dust ratio in nearby galaxies vary with properties such as Hubble type, metallicity, SFE, dust properties and c) it will contribute to an innovative method to calibrate dust as a tracer of gas and obtain molecular gas masses for 30,000 galaxies out to z~0.5.
